metadata.case_name: Central Talkies Ltd. v. Dwarka Prasad

facts.text: Dwarka Prasad was the sole owner of plot No.73/22 (old No. 73/28) situated in Collector gunj, Kanpur.

In 1933, an agreement of lease was executed by five persons in favour of Lala Rameshwardas, predecessor-in-title of Dwarka Prasad, by which five lessees took on lease a hall and other constructions which lessor agreed to build at a cost of Rs. 16,000/- within four months.
Lessor entitled to interest at 12 annas per cent per month if excess spent over Rs. 16,000/- till end of tenancy.
Tenancy was month to month, fixed at 5 years initially, continued with variations in rent till 1946.
On January 15, 1946, Dwarka Prasad sent letter to defendants (Central Talkies Ltd.) that lease period expires February 28, 1946, and they should vacate.
Defendants did not vacate, suit for ejectment filed against Central Talkies Ltd.
During pendency of suit, United Provinces Temporary Control of Rent and Eviction Act, 1947 (Eviction Act) came into force.
Under s.3 Eviction Act, permission of District Magistrate required to file eviction suit except on enumerated grounds; suit filed on non-enumerated ground, withdrawn.
Dwarka Prasad applied to District Magistrate for permission to eject Central Talkies Ltd.; permission granted by Additional District Magistrate (Rural Area) on July 7, 1948.
Application first made over to Mr. Hadi Hasan (Additional District Magistrate), who sent it back asking for transfer as approached by defendants.
District Magistrate passed order on February 11, 1948: 'Transferred to Additional District Magistrate (R.A.) for disposal.'
Application disposed by Mr. Brijpal Singh Seth, Additional District Magistrate (Rural Area), previously City Magistrate Kanpur.

Notification No. 3400/11-276-48 dated May 22, 1948 appointed Shri Brijpal Singh Seth as Additional District Magistrate of Kanpur District with all powers of District Magistrate under CrPC and any other law.
Suit No. 35 of 1949 filed; trial court (Civil Judge, Kanpur) judgment and decree dated May 24, 1954.
Allahabad High Court First Appeal No. 251 of 1954, judgment and decree dated September 21, 1955, reversing trial court, decreed suit for ejectment and damages at Rs. 593-12-0 per month.
Certificate granted by High Court under Art. 133(1)(b) Constitution for appeal to Supreme Court.
Appellants abandoned ground of invalid notice during arguments.

legal_issues.text: Whether the suit was competent, as permission under s.3 of the United Provinces Temporary Control of Rent and Eviction Act, 1947 was granted by Additional District Magistrate instead of District Magistrate.

petitioner_arguments.text: Suit incompetent because permission of District Magistrate as required by s.3 Eviction Act not obtained; District Magistrate is persona designata, only he or officer authorised by him can grant permission.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.3 and s.2(d) Eviction Act; s.10(2) CrPC; s.1(2) CrPC

petitioner_arguments.text: Order transferring case to Additional DM (R.A.) was mere transfer, not authorisation; transfer only to person with jurisdiction, which is confined to DM or authorised officer.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Kedar Nath Mool Chand (AIR 1953 All 62); P.K. Tare v. Emperor (AIR 1943 Nag 26)

petitioner_arguments.text: Notification under s.10(2) CrPC does not empower Additional DM under Eviction Act due to s.1(2) CrPC preserving special laws.

respondent_arguments.text: Additional District Magistrate (Raghubar Dayal J. view): Empowered by Provincial Government under s.10(2) CrPC to exercise all powers of DM under Code and all laws.
Additional District Magistrate (Brij Mohan Lal J. view): District Magistrate transferred case, authorising him under s.2(d) Eviction Act definition.

court_reasoning.text: Additional DM Mr. Brijpal Singh Seth competent via notification under s.10(2) CrPC investing him with all powers of DM under CrPC and any other law for time being in force.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No special authorisation from DM needed.

court_reasoning.text: s.1(2) CrPC does not override s.10(2) CrPC as latter is specific provision to contrary; Additional DM possesses powers under Eviction Act.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Argument based on s.1(2) CrPC overlooks 'in absence of specific provision to contrary'.

court_reasoning.text: District Magistrate not persona designata; definition in s.2(d) allows authorisation creating officers equated to DM.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Persona designata is individual acting in private capacity, not office holder like DM whose powers Additional DM can exercise.

court_reasoning.text: Transfer order deemed authorisation; even if mere transfer, valid as Additional DM had jurisdiction.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Reasons of High Court Judges valid.

court_reasoning.text: Allahabad case of Sapru J. erroneous.

holdings.text: Permission granted by Additional District Magistrate complies with s.3 Eviction Act; suit competent.

precedents_cited.relevance: Appellants relied on it for persona designata argument; court found erroneous.
Cited in Kedar Nath for similar proposition.
Definition of personae designatae as persons selected to act in private capacity.

statutes_cited.name: United Provinces Temporary Control of Rent and Eviction Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Required DM permission for eviction suit; DM includes officer authorised by DM.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898
statutes_cited.relevance: Empowers Provincial Govt to appoint Additional DM with all powers of DM under Code and other laws.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Certificate for appeal to Supreme Court.

statutes_cited.name: United Provinces Temporary Accommodation Requisition Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Definition of DM includes Additional DM explicitly, contrasted with Eviction Act.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court upheld High Court judgment decreeing suit for ejectment against appellants and awarding damages at Rs. 593-12-0 per month, holding permission under s.3 Eviction Act validly granted by Additional District Magistrate.

key_quotes.text: "District Magistrate is defined by s. 2(d) of the Act, which reads: 'District Magistrate includes an officer authorised by the District Magistrate to perform any of his functions under this Act.'"
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "The Notification... invested him with all the powers of the District Magistrate under the Code of Criminal Procedure as well as under any other law for the time being in force."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "A persona designata is a person who is pointed out or described as an individual, as opposed to a person ascertained as a member of a class."
key_quotes.speaker: court
